text: Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: And it’s good for you and for me. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, we do have, uh, uh, the one drug called, Xtandi. We have two clinical trials, and those trials are both trying to make the drug work better by combining it with other, other drugs- Patient: Hum. Doctor: That in some ways compliment the hormone therapy. Uh, both of the two trials that we have, though, do require a biopsy, and I don’t know, I’ll have to go back and look to see if they’d allow a bone biopsy.

text: Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
